title: Maryland’s highest court overhauls the state’s cash-based bail system
text:
February 7 at 4:33 PM Follow @OvettaWashPost The highest court in Maryland has overhauled the state’s cash-bail policy and directed judges not to set bail higher than what a defendant can afford — essentially abolishing a system in which poor people could languish behind bars before trial because they could not pay bond.
Kevin Kane, a spokesman for the Maryland Court of Appeals, said the new rule change will take effect July 1.
Maryland’s legislature has been debating whether to limit or eliminate cash bail for more than a decade. Advocates have urged the state to follow New Mexico, Kentucky and New Jersey, all of which have either changed or gotten rid of the money-based bail system in recent years.
Attorney General Brian E. Frosh tweeted that the rule change is a “huge win for justice in MD.”
Frosh asked the court late last year to consider changing the directives given to judges as they set bail.
He and other critics of the state’s bail system said that the current system was unfair and possibily unconstitutional.
This story will be updated.
